title: Live like royalty in London (for just $77,000 a night)
text:
Dan F Stapleton Writer Jun 6, 2019 — 12.02am Share

The crew of more than 100 firefighters had barely rolled up their hoses when Amanda Hyndman, the general manager of the Mandarin Oriental Hyde Park, hatched her plan.

She knew that the charred hotel – which had been mere days away from revealing a £100 million ($186 million) renovation – would need to close for quite some time while the damage from the multi-storey fire in June 2018 was repaired. But she was loath to make redundant one of the most skilled groups of staff in London.

“My priority was to keep the team together,” she says. “I knew they would be demotivated and quickly bored by not working and, at the same time, they were so highly qualified that our competitors would want to hire them.”

More than 100 firefighters were called to the Mandarin Oriental Hyde Park when a fire broke out on June 6, 2018. John Stillwell/AP

Hyndman, a veteran GM of Mandarin Oriental hotels in Bangkok and Washington, decided to retain her staff on full pay and benefits. Some were seconded to properties overseas, but most stayed in London, where they began volunteering for charities. Over nine months, Hyndman’s team donated 40,000 man-hours to local organisations, from Oxfam shops to food banks.

“We received a great deal of support from the London community during the fire emergency,” Hyndman says, “and giving away working hours to the city was a simple way to express our gratitude. But it also strengthened the bonds within our team.”

In April this year, the Mandarin Oriental Hyde Park London finally reopened, revealing at last that pricey new look by designer-du-jour Joyce Wang, who cites both legendary architect Frank Lloyd Wright and macabre filmmaker David Lynch as key influences.

The reimagined property is home to London’s most expensive hotel suite (a cool £42,000, or $77,000, a night), two restaurants by Michelin-starred chefs and what is arguably the city’s most impressive spa.

But Hyndman reckons its real competitive advantage lies elsewhere. “Our vision is to become one of the finest hotels in the world by offering kind and generous service,” she declares.

Of course, claims of superior service are common in the world of five-star hospitality – but Hyndman and her team have form. Their above-and-beyond mentality is chronicled in the 2017 TV series A Very British Hotel, which shows staff flying an American businesswoman’s breast milk back to her baby in Boston, and displaying remarkably good cheer as they deep-clean a suite that has been trashed by Middle Eastern royalty.
description: A year after a blaze ripped through the Mandarin Oriental Hyde Park, the reimagined hotel has risen from the ashes and is ready to impress.
